title: Are there elementary particles undiscovered in the universe? - Quora

response.answer_text: Not only are there no other elementary particles that are not already known, but some of the elementary particle that are known are not really elementary particles… let that sink in! What is undiscovered (and will always remain undiscovered) is the entity that is the building block of spacetime. These entities are NOT particles. Particles exist “in” spacetime. The component building block entities of spacetime exists “as” spacetime, not “in” spacetime. The energy associated with the entities of spacetime is proportional to c^0 and represents the base energy state in the three tiered hierarchy of energy expressed by this equation:  Physicists only know the energy that is associated with particles “in” spacetime. The known energy is the energy of light (photons) when G = 1 and m(subG) = h/wavelength and the energy of mass when G = 2 and m(sub2) = mass. During the big bang conditions existed for the E0 energy of spacetime to jump up to the higher energy states. After the big bang, E1 energy was not able to fall back to the base E0 energy state. This is why we have the law of conservation of energy. Gordon’s Theory of Everything reveals the internal energy structure of spacetime, photons and the elementary particles. If a particle cannot be derived using Gordon’s Theory of Everything, then the particle does not exist in reality. The Gordon model tells us that an elementary magnetic monopole particle is impossible to exist. It also tells us that the down quark cannot be an elementary particle. Gordon’s Theory of Everything shows that an electron and an up quark are elementary particles and that a down quark is a complex particle composed of an electron and an up quark. I sure this comes as a shock to physicists as they are totally committed to their current model BUT the Gordon model takes into consideration all the energy in the universe in its derivations and gives more details to the internal energy structure of particles. More importantly the Gordon model does not conflict with any accurate experimental data ever obtained but it does change the model.

From the point of view of standard physics, probably yes, although nothing unclassified has been found by the LHC. Some types of particles are theorised (gravitons, for example), whereas some are purely virtual models (the Higgs boson, even quarks, gluons…). Yet, it’s at least a bit questionable in the first place what a representation of a subatomic particle is, but the mathematical models based on them work mostly fine to some currently acceptable level. Here just recall that what we call a subatomic particle is a mathematical model in a framework of our currently acknowledged working theories in physics and that there are serious gaps in our ways of modeling them. Not to mention that many fundamental concepts used in physics are deeply logically flawed — for example, take spacetime and probabilistic wavefunctions/fields spread over it which are basically very useful concepts used together — however, their physical interpretation is not so “physical” after all, but a better model of them we haven’t had yet. (Btw, a funny side of this — you could add various imaginary particles/fields with their specific features to the Standard Model, which is considered to be a minimal acceptable set of modeling fields, just to do some fine tuning of some observed phenomena. So general this working model is, yet majority of observations falls into the acceptable error range of either the theory itself with this minimal set of elementary particles or related measurements.) On the other hand, most probably it is not a matter of finding “smaller” or “other type of” particles — rather, it is about how something is connected/related to something else. Briefly, what we consider to be spacetime with all the different particles/fields in it is a “high-level” behavioral model, an averaged mathematical “projection” of a discrete causal network made of extremely simple elements (“particles”, whatever). Here different families of subatomic particles and their associated properties are actually only classified various descriptive and averaged patterns in behavior of such a network (see the link above or my other answers related to the subject for more). In that context, we have probably identified most or major ones of these “behavioral patterns”, so to speak, yet some subtle ones are still waiting on us to be discovered. Everything said here was in my personal opinion. And, I really do respect physics and its achievements, so please consider the criticism shown above as positive.

Atom is the only particle so far discovered in the background science but with inadequate description of the Structure and inner Dynamics.Existence and behaviour of Electron and other energy particles such as Light and Heat have been discovered but structures and dynamics are not well defined.Neutron & Proton have been recognised but structure and dynamics are not explained at all.Vacuum medium is comprised with static medium particles (a combination of different sizes) and even its existence has not been assured in the background science.Existence of Dark Matter has been struck but neither Structure nor Dynamics explained in the background science.

In short and brief answer,nothing in science absolute as such,everything depends on the science and technology development, toward higher energy,resolution power and more accurate mathematical modeling to nature phenomena.Before 1897 the atom considered indivisible so it is the fundamental block in matter structure, its name in Creek is indivisible.But in 1897 discovered it is matter with electrons located as watermelon seeds,in 1911 the nucleus discovered with positive charge and it is the main mass of the atom,followed by discovering the nucleus constituents of the nucleus,the proton and neutron.Up to 1964 the nucleons considered as fundamental particles,but then they are found they are composed of quarks particles,their names has nothing to do with science,it is Gelmann fantasy.Now the fundamental particles are 16 quarks,leptons and Bosons. Is it possible new elementary particles be discovered ,the answer hung on up to new development.

With total respect and a lack of real grammar my apology I give now..I recon there is not much left to discover in the hunt for elements/particles..Physics pros Science geeks, Mathematicians have done the job in finding probably them all..its is the fabric of the spherical we are in..the links are what I believe hold each layer of fabric together,they are like tile separaters but with many more angle's in their structure for holding many layer's of connecting particles together in the map of precise placement of gazillions of connected productive links and creating a pure black vibrant space pre big bang and what is produced bye all galaxy holes in rehabilitation of the burn/bang..I am aware of the fact I'm not easily followed in my efforts to explain and worse on paper ..feel free to comment on it

Very likely. Three well established phenomena that might well be caused by or associated with a yet-to-be-discovered elementary particle are: The force of gravity (the graviton).A particle making up dark matter (Lambda-CDM).A (very speculative) particle making up dark energy.Mind you, the above could end up being the result of a complex soup of many (interacting?) particles. We simply don’t know what we don’t know.

Maybe… nobody knows for sure. Gravitons remain undiscovered. However, we do not know they exist. Same goes for tachyons. Stuff like that. We know that something must be responsible for dark matter… but we dont know fir a fact that dark matter is due to undiscovered elementary particles. It may be.
Likely. E.g., whatever dark matter is made of.
